body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

what type does SQL Server 2012 offer for arbitrarily large text that is unicode ?   NVARCHAR is a fixed size; unless SQL Server 2012 allows arbitrary-sized NVARCHAR that's not an option.

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **milestone** from "0.9.4" to "0.9.5"

**Landon Neale ([@lneale](https://github.com/lneale)) wrote:**

http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms187993.aspx

nvarchar is a variable length type

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

OK so this is TEXT also and they want to use varchar(max). 

However, this means that the Text()/ UnicodeText() types just shouldn't be used with SQL Server.  You can instead use String()/Unicode(), which will render as "varchar(max)" / "nvarchar(max)" right now if you don't give them a length.    

As it stands, changing Text/UnicodeText to spit out (n)varchar(max) seems like it would be pretty backwards incompatible/surprising for existing users.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

this is going to surprise people so it'll be for 1.0

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* removed labels: **low priority**

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **milestone** from "0.9.5" to "1.0"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- SQL Server 2012 now recommends VARCHAR(max), NVARCHAR(max),
VARBINARY(max) for large text/binary types.  The MSSQL dialect will
now respect this based on version detection, as well as the new
``deprecate_large_types`` flag.
fixes #3039


â†’ c8817e608788

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

issue.title: varbinary types fail w/ mssql + pyodbc + NULL
issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek))**

inserting a NULL into a VARBINARY requires that pyodbc.BinaryNull be used.  mxodbc probably has something similar.   The tests have been failing for a long time for this type since we added VARBINARY as a default type for LargeBinary in #3039.  which makes this a regression since 0.9 isn't doing that.

issue.title: SQL Server VARCHAR(MAX) on reflection can't compile or print
issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by adridg ([@adridg](https://github.com/adridg))**

With SQL Server, you can create columns of type VARCHAR(MAX). This is the modern rendition of NTEXT or TEXT, and SQL Alchemy translates String() into VARCHAR(MAX). With SQL Server 2012 or later, this happens automatically, and it's described in http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/changelog/changelog_10.html#change-f520106ec3455eaa056110c048aa4862 .

However, on reflection (through the inspector) you can end up with a VARCHAR (sql type-)object that has a length of "max" (i.e. a string). Printing that object causes an exception. As a very simple and contrived example:

from sqlalchemy import VARCHAR
print VARCHAR()
print VARCHAR(80)
print VARCHAR("max")  # Fails in _render_type_string

Attached find a simple test program that creates a table with a String() column, then reflects it to discover the VARCHAR(MAX) column.

----------------------------------------
Attachments: [t.py](../wiki/imported_issue_attachments/3504/t.py)
